summary: Did the Night king brand Bran?
body:
Did the Night king brand Bran?

I’ve never really understood the significance of this scene- when the night king touches Bran. Whatever magic prevented the NK from entering that cave was destroyed the moment he left his mark on Bran. That part I got BUT…

Does that also mean that he could defeat the magic of the wall because Bran crosses the wall still bearing his mark?

And do they share some kind of a connection now like Harry and Voldemort?

If you have answers, I’d really love to know what you think coz I just feel like it’s important.

If you have answers, I’d really love to know what you think coz I just feel like it’s important.

summary: There has been some recent speculation online that Bran is going to be, in one way or another, ruler of Westeros by the end of...
question: There has been some recent speculation online that Bran is going to be, in one way or another, ruler of Westeros by the end of ASOIAF. Do you think this is possible based on your readings of the books?
answer:
No. I think if Bran rules anywhere, it’ll be in Winterfell, and regardless of title I doubt he takes up day-to-day ruling, juggling competing factions and the fluctuations of the winter economy. Bran understands Winterfell differently to the way its temporal rulers do:

When he got out from under it and scrambled up near the sky, Bran could see all of Winterfell in a glance. He liked the way it looked, spread out beneath him, only birds wheeling over his head while all the life of the castle went on below. Bran could perch for hours among the shapeless, rain-worn gargoyles that brooded over the First Keep, watching it all: the men drilling with wood and steel in the yard, the cooks tending their vegetables in the glass garden, restless dogs running back and forth in the kennels, the silence of the godswood, the girls gossiping beside the washing well. It made him feel like he was lord of the castle, in a way even Robb would never know.

- Bran II, AGoT

I tend to think that the work of his life is to enable Winterfell to stand, thrive, and protect against winter, for another few thousand years.

title: Aegons and Brandons
body:
Today I was reading again, Kelsey L. Hayes very good post about Why Jon’s name is Aegon and here. There has been lots of chatter around why Aegon I conquered Westeros and whether or not he knew that a second long night would happen. And another article says GRRM confirmed it. (Though, some out there are still quibbling with this.) I don’t want to debate all that. What this did do was it got me thinking about the historic significance of the name Aegon. The discussion is leaning towards the fact that for TPTWP prophecy to work, the person had to be named Aegon. Hence, why we have a ton of Aegons.

We also have another historically significant name in the story, Brandon Stark.

We already pretty much know Jon and Bran will have to work together to defeat the WW/Others. I don’t particularly buy the Bran is the NK theory. We don’t know how or really why they have to work together. Other then Bran and Jon are one of the many representations of Ice and Fire in the story. There are also Stark and Targaryen, etc etc.  I hope that it’s more than Bran telling Jon what he has to do because Bran can see the past & future. There ‘Always has to be a Stark in Winterfell’ could it originally have been there ‘Always has to be a Brandon Stark in Winterfell’? Which is why we have a ton of Brandons in the Stark family. 

I also wonder if this is not only about defeating the WW/Others. That it’s about bringing about a peaceful kingdom. That North & South have to come together in winter and stay together in spring. A Brandon Stark with an Aegon Targaryen may need to be a part of this process. I also think a female Stark (Sansa or Arya) may need to be part of this.

This also rings very similarly to Aegon I and Orys Baratheon, Aegon’s rumored bastard-half brother,. Orys was a seasoned military commander. Very different from Bran. He did lose a hand later on. Consider Bran’s own disability and his connection to the handless Jaime Lannister…there could be something there.  I mean we’ve got Jon = Aegon, Arya = Visenya, Sansa = Rhaenys, Bran = Orys…all instrumental in the conquest. All part of unifying Westeros. Lots of differences of course with these characters. It’s not meant to be exactly the same esp. with Jon being their cousin. The dynamics are the same. The sisters have some very similar personality traits…Jon is literally named Aegon…so on and so on. 

At this point, I’m mulling these ideas around in my head. Would love to hear what you guys think. At the end of the day, an Aegon Targaryen and a Brandon Stark of the many Aegons and Brandons throughout history, have to work together during the second Long Night. That’s gotta mean a whole lot.

summary: Unpopular opinion.  I think Jon/Dany/tyrion are all bad rulers and I'm ok with their deaths.  I will be disappointed if we don't...
question: Unpopular opinion.  I think Jon/Dany/tyrion are all bad rulers and I'm ok with their deaths.  I will be disappointed if we don't have Sansa/arya/bran working together to fight the threats against Westeros and the rebuilding efforts afterwards.
answer:
You’re speaking my language anon. Tyrion is obviously the most talent of the three but he also blew up parts of King’s Landing and wondered why the smallfolk hated him afterwards. 

I personally think Jon x Dany x Tyrion are the most expendable characters who have something to do with the Others/White Walkers. GRRM can’t imagine them in a post apocalyptic world like he can Sansa, Arya and Bran so he has no problem killing them.

summary: What characters do you think have the best chances of a “happy” ending(i.e. they survive the end of the series and end in...
question: What characters do you think have the best chances of a “happy” ending(i.e. they survive the end of the series and end in circumstances where they can have a reasonably content, fulfilled life)? I would guess Sam, his arc is not a tragic one, nor does it seem likely to end in heroic sacrifice, since it’s all about how courage and heroism don’t have to be “glorious” & martial. Also Sansa who seems a great candidate to help put things back together in the aftermath. Possibly Arya as well.
answer: Yeah, the Starklings and Sam are the characters I’m pretty sure get a positive ending. I mean, they’ll have their losses, and their world will be a mess, but they’ll have surviving loved ones and meaningful work they’re prepared for and suited to. They’re the ones who’ll make the dream of spring a reality, I think.

They’re the ones who’ll make the dream of spring a reality, I think.

summary: Oddsmakers now rate Bran Stark as most likely to rule Westeros at the end of Game of Thrones

excerpt: Who will sit the Iron Throne at the end of Game of Thrones? That's the question on a lot of people's minds heading into the final season of the show. HBO ...
